reviews.review_msg: Do not take this course. There were so many weekly assignments to be done as both an individual and as a group. A total of 50% of the course's mark comes down to group work. Lectures are packed with redundant material, and the only reason for going is connecting with your group which you cannot pick. Grading at times felt random despite rubrics.

THE WORST!! Weekly group assignments, weekly individual assignments, multiple long papers, and a 10-page exam with two days to write it. Nice person, but horrible, unrealistic teaching style. I wouldn't recommend taking a class with him to anyone. Hopefully, I can save someone from making this mistake.

Dr. Pickup is a fair, clear professor who makes an otherwise complicated course easy to understand. However, the second half of the course is SIGNIFICANTLY harder than the first half! It was blended, so my recommendation is to go to the in-person lectures for that part of the course. Assignments were all doable and marking was generous.

Well, I overall think that he is a decent professor, but in most situations, the TA plays a much more important role than him. I am not sure if this is because the course is online or if there are other reasons for it.
Confusing course, no overlap between lectures and tutorials. Felt like two different courses.

Mark's recorded lectures were the only thing needed to learn the course content. He used many examples and explained almost every concept clearly. His in-person tutorials were helpful but not necessary. Overall good professor.

The lectures were delivered remotely, with tutorials, midterm and final in person. He provided a practice test for the midterm, which really helped as most of the questions were similar to the actual midterm. He also gave us a catchup week and a reading week which was super helpful to students who were behind. I would totally recommend!
Provides multiple options to demonstrate knowledge of course material. Mark also is open to feedback from students and will try to organize the course in response to students' requests.

Let's you choose how you want your assignments weighted. Presentation/Case study  group assignments and were fairly easy if you had good group members (I didn't :/). Final was take home ten page assignments (go to office hours, figure out what he's looking for). Readings/lecture  waste of time after the case study (final doesn't test on them).

Lectures were long and sometimes hard to get through but Mark adjusted the class well to an online learning environment and was very accessible. TB is provided but is honestly useless outside of the small assignments because the midterm/final were straight out of the lecture slides. One of the few classes I recommend taking online.

The syllabus and the actual course content were very different, although Mark is a very nice guy, his class was all over the place. The paper and presentation are done in a group with a fairly straight forward take-home exam. However, pop quizzes were brutal with very low averages. Lectures were dry and often went over useless quant research.

super nice guy, but other than that he is terrible. Fake news lecture was nothing what it seemed to be on syllabus when signing up for this course. He is all over the place during lecture, you really have to pay attention in order to follow what he is saying. Presentation & paper assignment is a waste of time. Find something more meaningful
This guy doesn't lecture, he mumbles. Super picky about details in essays and not in a good way. Really anxious lecturer, doesn't answer questions directly. Super nice guy though

Mark was great, I had no background knowledge and was very anxious to take a math heavy class  but he made it simple. I still had to work pretty hard to do well, but unless you completely slack off, you should be able todo okay. His exams are straight forward, he gives practice tests which are very similar. If I had to take a class with him again

Hes an excellent prof, just be sure to read the lecture slides before class and you'll do great. His lectures are very informative, so unless you contextualize the info, you may get a little lost at times.

Overall he's a great prof. He tries to keep stats as entertaining as possible. I found his examples made the material less intimidating and easier to understand. You should definitely read the chapters being discussed before attending the lecture though.
He makes his notes unnecessarily complicated... takes a lot of time to decipher what he means to say.

Good attitude, good sense of humour, and good slides. This class taught me a lot about statistics and many of the key things to remember about both linear and logistic regression. I recommend to anyone who is a serious poli sci major or is interested in statistics for poli sci.

His first undergrad was in Physics. So the science part of political science is the key to a good grade in this course. If pol201 didn't make you smile I'd avoid 315 unless you enjoy failing hilariously. Ask him a question and be prepared to hear EVERYTHING about what you asked about. He probably dreams in binary.

Horrible class! although the topic sounds interesting teacher's interest in teaching the class was absent; instead of four hours he barely did 1-1:30; his 4 lectures were useless because he just reiterated the readings. For a W course the workload was extremely low and not helpful at all; as a Q, stats were basically nonexistent. Avoid the class!

Mark is a fantastic prof and a great person.  The guy has forgotten more about statistics than most people will ever know.  If you want to walk out of a class with more marketable skills than the grad students at SFU, take his class.  If you struggled in 201, then run.

I had Mark for both Poli 315 and 426. He is a good guy and I recommend him to anyone thinking about taking one of his clases. He has a dry sense of humour, that he uses well to spice up boring material. My only complaint about Mark is he is not always clear about his expectations for assignments, and a tad inconsistent with marking.
